This is accurate, except the Sun is not yellow, it’s white. Pictures from space show that the sun is white. On the other hand, the sun appears yellow from Earth. 1) At 1:10 - Red light has the lowest frequency followed by yellow light (that our naked eyes can see). You said that the greater the frequency of a wavelength the more it scatters by the air particles it hits and thus the less frequency a light has the more that type of light will reach our eyes when we look directly at the sources of the light (because it scatters the least). So by your explanation the sun should look mostly red when we look at it or around it, but it looks mostly yellowish-white and not red, how's that possible?
2) At 1:16 You say that there are more air particles around when the sun sets and thus even more higher frequency wavelength light will scatter because more air particles are present for the light to scatter and so we get even richer orange-red colors at sunset. But why aren't the sky even more blue at sunset? By your explanation there are more air particles presents and so more blue light scatters, so when we look away from the sun the sky should look even more blue at sunset than at 1 pm for instance but in fact the sky looks reddish and not blue, how's that possible, since red light scatters the least? I understand the explanation on why the sun looks more red-orange at sunset when you look directly at it or near it, but I fail to understand why the sky themselves are painted yellow-orange-red even way you look away from the sun, shouldn't they be more deep blue when you look away from the sun?
An explanation would be much appreciated.

Anyone who asks why the sky should be sometimes green at some point: It really gets on some sunrises and -sets even though just partly but still existing. Blue is the word we use to describe the color we see when we look at the sky on a clear day.
Scattering the blue wavelength of light is literally the definition of the colour blue. If you say the sky's colour is not blue, then how do you define colour at all?

What's really mindblowing is that none of the millions of colors we perceive actually exist.  Colors are not an intrinsic property of light. They are just values assigned by our brains to the various frequencies of visible light.  The world as it actually exists is basically like a black and white photograph, with each object having varying intensity depending upon the frequency at which you view it  Our brains take all these different frequencies of light and synthesize a colorful model of the outside world.

Color vision confers a powerful evolutionary advantage, and that is why it persists in nature.

No, no, that's a common misunderstanding.  The real reason the sky is blue is because of Daylight Savings Time.  You see in the winter it's too cold to get any good work done, so we take away some of the daylight from winter and save it up, mostly the blue light because it stays good the longest.  That's why winter skies tend to be so grey and the days are so short.  Then starting in the spring when it warms up and people can do more work they start releasing all that blue light and it makes the days longer and the sky more blue.

"The sky is not blue." - Wrong. You have a flawed concept of color. Many physicists are prone to this one; color is not equivalent to the wavelength of light. While indeed, not 100% of the light coming out of the sky into your eyes is of a wavelength that would appear as blue on a spatial and temporal background of light of equally distributed wavelengths, the sky is blue nonetheless, in short simply because it appears as such, and this is what we call it. Color is an attribute our visual sensory system assigns to visual cues, it's part of our visual perception, nothing that is - or has a full equivalent - in the physical world anywhere outside of our brains.

@AngelGonzalez It wouldn't matter, but if you're asking the question "why is the sky blue?" Then "Because it looks blue" is not a satisfactory answer. Especially not from a scientific point of view.

Interesting implication for artists: As the clear blue sky is a source of diffuse light (going in all directions), shadows aren't all dark (as they are on the moon, where anything in the shadow is only illuminated by starlight). On a clear sunny day, objects in direct sunlight appear slightly yellowish, the same objects in shadow appear blueish because the main light source in the shadow is the blue sky. Take this into account when creating a colour painting; you get a very sunny effect by not only adding hard dark shadows but also by making the shadows blue and adding a slight yellow tinge to what is in sunlight.

On a cloudy day however, all light is diffuse, the sky is grey, there are no hard shadows and those don't have a colour.

An example of how the scattering (and the curvature of the earth) affects visibility:

Both images were shot from Koliba at Kamzík in Bratislava with the same lens, just with different cameras (one converted to near IR)

The first image is shot in "visible light" (give or take 390 - 720 nm wavelength):
https://drive.google.com/file/d/0B-uGqWB0p-REYUQ1ZVJDY042Ukk/view?usp=sharing

This second image is shot in the near infrared (about 720 to 900 nm):
https://drive.google.com/file/d/0B-uGqWB0p-REdmRoMk5NeklVcHc/view?usp=sharing

See the difference? While visible light showed up to 55 km to the cooling towers of the Bohunice Nuclear Power Plant, the IR spectrum showed the Považský inovec mountains, about 100 km away. The atmosphere did scatter all the short wavelengths of (reflected) light of the visible spectrum from far away, but the longer near IR light passed, or at least a part of it. IR is less affected by Rayleigh scattering, Mie scattering, by mist and by haze than all colors of visible light (the entire visible light range). That is why the IR image shows also the distant mountains. And no, you can try to boost contrast on the visible light image as far as you want, there is nothing there (I tried it when processing the RAW files, believe me).

Another funny thing: Notice the sudden drop in contrast in the IR image at the level of the nuclear power plant? You might expect that this line forms the horizon behing which we cannot see due to earth curvature. We can find out:

The picture was taken from a height about 400 meters above sea level and the power plant is about 175 meters above sea level. Taking the elevations I wrote here (got them from a hiking map) and using basic geometry maths taking into account also the refraction of the atmosphere (used the values defined for visible light also for near infrared as there is little difference), the calculations say the horizon (or the nuclear power plant on the horizon) should be 58,5 km away. This nicely fits with the measured distance of 55 km using google maps. It is so nice when things work out!

But how do we see the mountains in the background? Well, they are high, reaching up to 640 - 900 meters in height, so they "rise" behind the horizon. Basically the IR photo shows everything up to the horizon at a distance of about 58 km and then the background at a distance of roughly 100 km. You cannot see anything between the horizon and the hills due to earth curvature.

But you would not see the background anyway as you are limited by your eyes to the part of electromagnetic spectrum that we call visible light. The visibility was rather very good when I took the picutres, the conditions are often much worse, so you cannot see even the cooling towers of the nuclear powerplant. Even the visible light image taken at a rather very good visibility conditions has just a faint picture of them.

Next time I will try to "see" (using both visible and near IR) the Apls in Austria from Devínska Kobya. It should also be about 100 km. And I should also see Vienna, just on the horizon.
